citations.narrative:
A section of the fencing located above the most westerly lynx pen did not meet the ground leaving an approximate two-
foot-tall gap over approximately six-foot length of fence large enough for animals or humans to pass through. This fence
serves as the primary enclosure for the reindeer and the perimeter fence for the lynx and fox enclosures contained within.
Inadequate perimeter fencing can allow for access of unauthorized persons and other animals and fail to act as
secondary containment for the animals in the facility. This could lead to injury, escape, or death of the animal.
All outdoor housing must be enclosed by a perimeter fence unless the animals are exempt (reindeer). The perimeter
fence must protect the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or
under it and having contact with the animals in the facility. The perimeter fence must also function as secondary
containment for the animals housed within.
This is a 3rd Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
The applicant is not currently in compliance with the AWA as documented above. You may appeal this finding in writing by
October 9, 2024.
Appeals should be addressed to:
Ms. Sarah Helming
Deputy Administrator
APHIS Animal Care AC)
U.S. Department of Agriculture
4700 River Road | 6D-03F
Riverdale, MD 20787
Or emailed to:
animalcareappeals@usda.gov
Your existing license has expired and a new license will not be issued. Conducting regulated activities without a valid
USDA license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
Additional Inspectors:
ANDREA D AMBROSIO, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
A section of the fencing located above the most westerly lynx pen did not meet the ground leaving an approximate two-
foot-tall gap over approximately six-foot length of fence large enough for animals or humans to pass through. This fence 
serves as the primary enclosure for the reindeer and the perimeter fence for the lynx and fox enclosures contained within. 
 
Inadequate perimeter fencing can allow for access of unauthorized persons and other animals and fail to act as 
secondary containment for the animals in the facility. This could lead to injury, escape, or death of the animal. 
 
All outdoor housing must be enclosed by a perimeter fence unless the animals are exempt (reindeer). The perimeter 
fence must protect the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or 
under it and having contact with the animals in the facility. The perimeter fence must also function as secondary 
containment for the animals housed within. 
 
This is a 3rd Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
The applicant is not currently in compliance with the AWA as documented above. You may appeal this finding in writing by 
October 9, 2024. 
 
Appeals should be addressed to: 
Ms. Sarah Helming 
Deputy Administrator 
APHIS Animal Care AC) 
U.S. Department of Agriculture 
4700 River Road | 6D-03F 
Riverdale, MD 20787 
 
Or emailed to:

animalcareappeals@usda.gov 
 
Your existing license has expired and a new license will not be issued. Conducting regulated activities without a valid 
USDA license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
